sec.title: Hands-On Approaches Using a CRDS Analyser
Overview of the CRDS Techniques for Determining GHG Concentrations and Soil Fluxes
sec.p: AsCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) outlined in Sect. 2.6 (“Analysis of GHGGreenhouse Gases (GHGs) samples with optical gas analysers”), the advent of laser-based techniques has enabled real-timeReal-time measurement of soil gas fluxes in the field. In recent years, CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) has become of particular interest to researchers due to its ability to measure GHGGreenhouse Gases (GHGs) concentrations with a very high precisionPrecision in field settings. For example, the PicarroPicarro ®G2508 multi-speciesMultispecies gas analyzer gas analyser allows CO2Carbon dioxide (CO2), CH4Methane (CH4), N2ONitrous oxide (N2O), NH3Ammonia (NH3), and H2OWater vapour (H2O) to be measured simultaneously. CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analysers have three key advantages for soil gas flux measurements in comparison to traditional GCGas Chromatograph (GC) measurements: (1) it enables the detection and measurement of low levels of GHGGreenhouse Gases (GHGs) fluxes. Areas with low emission rates, while not significant in the short-term, may be of great interest to calculate the global GHGGreenhouse Gases (GHGs) budget when extrapolated over longer timescales and large surface areas; (2) multi-species measurements allow for direct correlations between gas species. The processes and sources associated with the emission (or uptake) of GHGsGreenhouse Gases (GHGs) may require more than one axis for proper characterisation; and (3) the high sampling frequency of real-timeReal-time measurements leads to a better characterisation of soil flux profiles and shorter closure times for soil flux chambers. In addition, the real-timeReal-time nature of this system provides instant feedback on site selection and omits sampling and storageStorage effects.

The sub-section below describes the fundamentals of CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) and discusses how a CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser may be paired with commercial and home-made closed chambersClosed chamber to create a field and/or laboratory deployable flux system.

sec.title: Theory: Near-Infrared Absorption Spectroscopy Fundamentals
sec.p: Nearly every small gas-phase moleculeSpectroscopy (e.g. H2OWater vapour (H2O), CO2Carbon dioxide (CO2), CH4Methane (CH4), N2ONitrous oxide (N2O), etc.) has a unique near-infraredNear Infrared (NIR) absorption spectrum, and this is generally also true for different isotopologuesIsotopologue (12CO2Carbon dioxide (CO2) vs. 13CO2, 12CH4 vs. 13CH4, etc.) (for details, see Chap. 7). At atmospheric pressure, these spectra are very broad and continuous, but at sub-atmospheric pressure the contributions from individual vibrational modes are well resolved so that each spectrum is made up of distinct absorption lines; each line is centred at a characteristic wavelengthWavelength and possesses an extremely predictable line shape. Under these conditions, it is generally possible to find one or more narrow wavelengthWavelength frequency ranges where the target molecule has strong absorbance features, and the absorbance contributions from other molecules are minimal. Therefore, the spectrum for each molecular species can be thought of as a unique and very information-rich “fingerprint”.

sec.title: Operational Principle of Cavity Ring-Down Spectroscopy
sec.p:
Cavity ring-down spectroscopy allows the concentration and isotopic Spectroscopycomposition of gases to be measured with very high precisionPrecision. A key feature of CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) is that it measures the decay of light in the measurement cell instead of measuring absolute absorption intensities, where the term “ring down” in CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) is referring to this principle of measuring the light loss in the cavity over time. The cavity itself consists of three high reflectivity mirrors, and the light from a continuous-wave, single-frequency tunable laser diode is reflected between the mirrors (Fig. 2.8). When the laser is turned on, the cavity quickly fills with the circulating laser light. Because the mirrors have slightly less than 100% reflectivity (99.999%), a small amount of light continuously leaks out and is measured with the photodetector. As soon as the light intensity reaches a threshold (within a few tens of microseconds), the laser is abruptly turned off, and the light already within the cavity bounces between the mirrors (about 100,000 times). As the light circulates between the mirrors, light is absorbed by the target gas in the cavity, and the photodetector measures the exponential decay curve, also known as ring downs. In the absence of the absorbing gas, the decay rate is determined solely by the reflectivity of the mirrors.Fig. 2.8
High finesse optical cavity with a three-mirror configuration. Top: no absorbing species in the cavity = long ring-down time. Bottom: absorbing species present in the cavity = short ring-down time

The ring downs are measured in real timeReal time by the photodetector, and the exponential decay curve consists of several thousand individual light measurements. A dedicated signal processor fits this curve to determine the decay rate. To obtain a spectrum, the laser frequency is tuned over a sequence of narrow frequencies, and the ring-down rate is measured for each step (Fig. 2.9). Once a spectrum is obtained, algorithms are used to recover the spectrum contributions from each gas and from backgroundBackground, background emission light loss processes, as previously described. Critically, the decay rates are independent of the initial laser light intensity, and as such, the measurement is not affected by laser intensity fluctuations or absolute laser power.Fig. 2.9
The laser frequency is stepped, and a ring-down measurement is made at each step, generating a series of exponential decay curves (left). The softwareSoftware fits each curve to discover its decay coefficient. Representing these coefficients as absorbance, we obtain an absorbance spectrum (right). Numbers indicate corresponding decay curves and absorbance spectrum data

sec.title: Minimum Detectable Flux (MDF)
sec.p: CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS)analysersMinimum Detectable Flux (MDF)allow GHGGreenhouse Gases (GHGs) concentrations to be measured with a higher frequency and precisionPrecision than generally possible with GCGas Chromatograph (GC) techniques. These key advantages allow either to determine GHGGreenhouse Gases (GHGs) fluxes with a higher precisionPrecision or to achieve the same level of precisionPrecision within a shorter amount of time. The latter is of importance because a reduction in enclosure time minimises negative effects resulting from the use of a closed static chamber.

sec.title: Selecting the Appropriate Flow Path
sec.p: CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS)analysersFlow path have a continuous flow-through design that pulls gas through the analyser at a fixed flow rate (typical flow rate for a concentration CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser is ~250 ml min−1). AutomatedAutomation, automated pressure control loops within the analyser can be adjusted to gradual changes in input pressure and flow, but under normal operation, gas enters and leaves the analyser at the same flow rate. This design characteristic makes it suitable for use in recirculation experiments. Depending on the chamber design, the CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser can act as the primary source of flow or as a secondary sampling source, referred to as in-line or parallel, respectively.

sec.title: In-Line Flow Path
sec.p:
In this setup, theFlow pathCRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser is typically the primary source and control of flow in the recirculation setup (Fig. 2.11). It is commonly used with custom-made chambers or commercial chambers that do not employ their own flow control. When designing such a setup, users need to be mindful of any restrictions or rapid changes of flow that may occur during measurement. Inlet tubingTubing length should not exceed 15 m and should have appropriate filtration in place to protect the analyser from dust and liquid waterWater (see the next section). The CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser acts as the primary data repository for concentration and external sensor data (chamber temperatureTemperature regulation, temperature and pressure) and can control and coordinate chamber operation (if available).Fig. 2.11
Flow pathFlow path of an in-line arrangement with a CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser in combination with a recirculation pump and a soil chamber. Additional communication or control cables are not shown

sec.title: Parallel Flow Path
sec.p: The parallel flow arrangement isFlow path typically used when the analyser acts as a complementary or additional instrument in an existing recirculation setup. The user may have an existing flow setup that is controlled by a primary pump, or they may be using an existing chamber-analyser system (e.g. LI-CORLi-Cor ® LI-8100A, for details, see Chap. 3, Sect. 3.2.2). Since the CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser is no longer the primary source of flow control, it is essential that the flow rate of the main recirculation setup is higher than that of the CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser. The greater the difference between the two, the smaller the influence of the CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser will be.

sec.title: Multiple Chambers
sec.p: It should be noted that many commercial and homemade chambers often come with multiplexers–the ability to deploy and connect multiple chambers to a single analyser. A CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser can be used with a multiplexer in both the in-line or parallel arrangements.

The connection location of the CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser should follow the same approach as shown in Figs. 2.12 and 2.13. In either case, the multiplexer is located in the place of the chamber.Fig. 2.12

Additional communication and control cables are not shown. Note the higher flow rate of the main recirculation setup at 1000 ml min−1, and the parallel connection of the CRDSCavity Ring Down Spectrometer (CRDS) inlet and return on the return flow of the LI-CORLi-Cor ® analyserFig. 2.13

sec.title: Calibration
sec.p:
The concentration readings ofCalibrationa CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser behave very stable over time, and therefore, it is not necessary to calibrate the concentrations daily or weekly. However, it is advisable to check the accuracyAccuracy and performance of a CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser on a monthly to yearly basis. This can be done by measuring standardsStandard from compressed gas cylinders. The concentrations measured by the CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser are then compared to the accepted value of the gas cylinder. The quality/accuracyAccuracy of the final analyser calibrationCalibration reflects (1) the number of standardsStandard, (2) the compositional range of the standardsStandard, (3) the methodMethod of standardStandard measurement, and (4) the accuracyAccuracy and precisionPrecision of the standardStandard itself:
The minimum number of different standardsStandard to calibrate the slope and offset of the analyser is two, and because CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) instruments are highly linear, this is often enough. However, it is recommended to measure at least three or more standardsStandard, to confirm both the linearity of the instrument and the quality of the standardsStandard.
The range of the standardsStandard should generally encompass or exceed the expected concentration range of the sample air and should fall within the guaranteed specification range of the analyser.
The gas cylinders can either be connected directly to the CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser or the gas can be introduced via a gas bag (e.g. Tedlar bag). Direct connections to a tank are preferred as they minimise the chance of leaks and eliminate any dilutionDilution of the standardStandard from remnant gas in the bag. Tedlar bags are an acceptable option, but they may lead to a lower degree of confidence in calibrationCalibration. For applications where 1–10 ppm levels of accuracyAccuracy are required, a direct connection to a tank is recommended.
It is commonly accepted that primary standardsStandard, when compared to secondary or even tertiary standardsStandard, have higher levels of accuracyAccuracy. Having confidence in the value of the standards leads to a higher degree of confidence in the calibrationCalibration of the instrument. It is advisable to assess whether the accuracyAccuracy and precisionPrecision of the standardsStandard are high enough for the research needs.

sec.title: Advanced Application Considerations: Filtration of Gas Samples
sec.p: The precisionPrecision of an absorption measurement within a CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser can degrade under the presence of foreign particles that scatter or absorb light. To overcome this potential issue, the inlet of a CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser is generally equipped with two 4 nm particulate filters. One is user-replaceable, and the other can only be replaced in a cleanroom environment. To prevent long-term damage to the sample handling of the analyser and maintain a healthy cavity, external filters are recommended.

Of primary concern are particles that can potentially be pulled into the sample handling of the analyser via the inlet port. In order to select and build a proper filtration system, the user must first assess which, if any, particles are potentially present in the field. Arid environments with high wind speeds or other mechanical means of increasing particle load (walking, driving, animals, etc.) pose a much greater danger to the analyser than vegetated surfaces. In most cases, a cheap, user-replaceable Acrodisc®, 0.2–1 µm is enough to remove most particles. The frequency of replacement should be dictated by the particle load of the gas sample and the flow rate through the filter.

sec.title: Liquid Water and Water Vapour
sec.p: One of the biggest risks to any field-basedWatersystemWater vapour (H2O) is exposure to liquid water. In this section, we focus on the introduction of liquid water through the inlet of the analyser as a result of (1) condensation or (2) actual sampling of liquid water (precipitation, ground saturation, etc.).

Long-term deployments of CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analysers can subject them to environments with temperatureTemperature regulation, temperature variations that exceed the operating range of the system (10–35 °C). Custom or commercially available enclosures are used to provide a measure of temperatureTemperature regulation, temperature control and/or protection from the elements (rain, snow, wind, etc.). The temperatureTemperature regulation, temperature difference between the exterior and interior of the enclosure can lead to condensation in sampling lines. This problem is particularly evident in scenarios where hot and humid gas is brought into a cold enclosure. To reduce the likelihood of condensation, desiccants such as Drierite or magnesium perchlorate can be used to reduce the waterWater vapour (H2O) vapour level in the sample gas. Such desiccants are also practical if water vapors need to be reduced below 4 vol%, the operational limit for a CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser.

If condensation, or the presence of liquid waterWater through direct sampling, cannot be avoided, then a water trap must be used before the inlet of the analyser. The volume of a water trap should be appropriate to handle any input of liquid water. It is also possible to install water traps with automatic draining capability so that the system may operate in a user-free fashion. It is important to note that a water trap will add additional volume to the recirculation system, something that needs to be considered when flux calculations are performed.

sec.title: CRDS-Specific Considerations
sec.p:
A CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser is a laser absorption spectrometer. Under specific conditions, the composition of the sample gas may have unintended effects on the spectra. If levels of ethane, ethylene, acetyleneAcetylene (C2H2), or hydrogenHydrogen (H2) sulphide exceed atmospheric levels, the user should consult manufacturer documentation to determine the effects of these species on their measurements of greenhouse gasesGreenhouse Gases (GHGs). In many cases, the installation of an additional scrubber may be used to remove an interfering species. One such example is the removal of hydrogenHydrogen (H2) sulphide using laboratory-grade copper filings (Malowany et al. 2015). The composition of the carrier gasCarrier gas, specifically any significant changes to the N2Dinitrogen (N2)–O2Oxygen (O2) ratio of the carrier gasCarrier gas, will have pressure broadening effects on the spectra (Nara et al. 2012). This can result in a degradation of accuracyAccuracy. The installation of an additional oxygenOxygen (O2)sensor inside a CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser, or any external oxygenOxygen (O2) sensor, can help the user detect changes in theDinitrogen (N2) N2–O2Oxygen (O2) ratio and apply a correction. The manufacturer also offers a pre-configured mode for pure N2Dinitrogen (N2)carrier gasesCarrier gas. It should be noted that major changes to ArgonArgon (Ar) (Ar) or HeliumHelium (He) (He) will have the same effects. More importantly, a pure He carrier can permanently damage a CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser.

sec.title: Datalogging and Flux Processing
sec.p: All concentration data obtained using aFlux processingCRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analyser is automatically stored on the hard drive of the analyser. This raw data can then be processed using the CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS)softwareSoftware or other, third-party compatible softwareSoftware that is usually supplied by the chamber manufacturer to obtain flux values. In order to convert concentrations into fluxes, the softwareSoftware will ask the user to enter the chamber and tubingTubing volume, chamber surface area, chamber and soil temperatureTemperature regulation, temperature, and chamber pressure. Depending on the softwareSoftware package used, it may be possible to monitor the accumulation of the gases in real timeReal time or apply post-processing using three or more fitting algorithms: linear (Eq. 2.9), quadratic (Eq. 2.10) (Wagner et al. 1997), or Hutchinson and Mosier (1981) (Eq. 2.11).

Custom fitting options are available in certain softwareSoftware packages (Fig. 2.15).Fig. 2.15

CRDSCavity Ring-Down Spectrometer (CRDS) analysers are compatible with the streaming of data to external dataloggerDatalogging, datalogger using RS232, Ethernet, or analogue communication protocols. In addition, it is also possible to incorporate external sensor data such as pressure and temperatureTemperature regulation, temperature probes within the soil flux chamber. Detailed support and integration documentation are available from the manufacturer.

sec.title: Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy of Greenhouse Gases
sec.p: Enhanced Raman spectroscopyRaman spectroscopy emerged in recent years asGreenhouse Gases (GHGs) a powerful analytical tool for highly selective identification and simultaneous quantification of multiple components in complex gas mixtures (Hanf et al. 2014; Frosch et al. 2013a; Jochum et al. 2015a; Hippler 2015; Kiefer 2015; Knebl et al. 2017). Conventional Raman spectroscopyRaman spectroscopy was already discovered in the 1920th (Long 2002; Smekal 1923; Raman and Krishnan 1928; Landsberg and Mandelstam 1928; Kramers and Heisenberg 1925), but its application in real-world applications was very limited until recently, due to the inherently weak signal intensities and technical limitations.

sec.title: Raman Spectroscopy of Gases
sec.p:
Raman spectroscopy is based onRaman spectroscopy inelastic scattering of light. When monochromatic laser light is guided through a gas sample, most photons pass the analyte volume without any interaction and thus provide no gas specific chemical information. The scattering cross section σ is only around 10−27 cm2 for typical gases. Thus, only a small fraction of the photons is scattered by the gas molecules which also have a very low number density. The major part of the scattered radiation results from elastic scattering (Rayleigh scattering) and has the same frequency as the excitation light. Inelastic scattering occurs with approximately three orders of magnitude smaller intensity. The frequency shift of the inelastically scattered light is caused by the energy transfer in the rotational, vibrational, or rotational–vibrational states of the molecules and is thus the basis of the unique chemical selectivity of Raman spectroscopyRaman spectroscopy. Raman scattering and the more established IRInfrared (IR) absorption are complementary effects that probe molecular vibrations and rotations. Raman scattering depends on the changes in the polarisability of the molecule during the rotation/vibration, while IRInfrared (IR) absorption relies on changes in the (permanent) dipole moment. Thus, IRInfrared (IR) absorption spectroscopy is not sensitive to diatomic homonuclear molecules such as oxygenOxygen (O2) (O2), hydrogenHydrogen (H2) (H2), or nitrogen (N2Dinitrogen (N2)) which provide no permanent dipole moment for light interaction. In contrast, inelastic Raman scattering does not require a permanent dipole moment of the molecules, and the specific molecular transitions must not be matched with the excitation wavelengthWavelength. Thus, Raman spectroscopyRaman spectroscopy is a powerful methodMethod for the analysis of all but noble gases with only one monochromatic laser source. A whole suite of biogenic gases, including CO2Carbon dioxide (CO2), N2ONitrous oxide (N2O), O2Oxygen (O2), CH4Methane (CH4), H2Hydrogen (H2), and N2Dinitrogen (N2), can be identified and quantified simultaneously (Fig. 2.16).Fig. 2.16

sec.title: Enhanced Raman Gas Spectroscopy
sec.p: The originally small inelastic scattering signals of the gas molecules must be increased with the development of enhancement techniques based on the above-given parameters in order to achieve high sensitivities. Raman gas sensors are nowadays based on specific multi-pass cavities, high-pressure cells, or the application of high-power lasers (Li et al. 2008; Kiefer et al. 2008; Schiel and Richter 1987). Two very promising techniques, which were recently developed, are fibre-enhanced Raman spectroscopyFibre-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (FERS) (FERS) (Hanf et al.2014; Knebl et al. 2018) and cavity-enhanced Raman spectroscopyCavity-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (CERS) (CERS) (Frosch et al 2013a).

In FERSFibre-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (FERS), the number N of gas molecules that contribute to the Raman signal (Eq. 2.10) is extremely increased. In conventional Raman spectroscopyRaman spectroscopy, the signal is excited and collected from a small scattering volume (Fig. 2.17a) (Frosch et al. 2013b). This limitation can be overcome with the help of hollow-core optical sensor fibres. In elaborated micro-structured hollow-core optical fibres, the light can be guided with extremely low attenuation within a certain spectral range (Russell 2003; Knight 2003; Hartung et al. 2015; Yan et al. 2017a, b). By filling the gas in the same inner hollow core of the fibre, light and analyte are both guided in the same volume and thus the analyte is efficiently excited over an extended path length (Fig. 2.17b) and the number of scattering molecules is strongly increased (Frosch et al. 2013b). In other words, the Raman fibre sensor can be seen as optimised cuvette and provides strongly enhanced analytical sensitivity (Hanf et al. 2014; Frosch et al. 2013b; Knebl et al. 2019; Jochum et al. 2016; Hanf et al. 2015a; Boegoezi et al. 2015; Sieburg et al. 2019). A highly efficient FERSFibre-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (FERS) setup was developed for gas analysisRaman spectroscopic gas analysis (Figs. 2.17 and 2.18).Fig. 2.17
Comparison of conventional Raman spectroscopyRaman spectroscopy (a) and fibre-enhanced Raman spectroscopyRaman spectroscopy (b). Conventional Raman setups suffer from the limited interaction volume of excitation light and analyte gas (a). In FERSFibre-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (FERS), the excitation light is guided over an extended range within the hollow core of the optical fibre, which also functions as minimised analyte container (b). An excellent light–analyte interaction is achieved in fibre-enhanced Raman spectroscopyRaman spectroscopy and a high number of molecules contribute to the Raman signal (Frosch et al. 2013b).

In CERSCavity-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (CERS), the weak inelastic scattering signals of the gas molecules can be increased by up to six orders of magnitude with the help of a high finesse optical cavity. One of the developed gas sensors consists of a miniaturised laser diode with λexc. = 650 nm (Frosch et al. 2013a; Keiner et al. 2013, 2014) which is passively frequency locked and feedback coupled to a high finesse cavity, enabling a power build-up to 100 W (Frosch et al. 2013a). The cavity components are aligned for spatial mode matching of the input beam and the Gaussian beam supported by the power build-up cavityPower Build-Up Cavity (PBC) (PBC), while the facet of the laser diode helps in stabilising mode matching by spatial filtering (Frosch et al. 2013a). Such arrangement of the PCB is extremely stable to mechanical vibrations (Frosch et al. 2013a), and it has been shown that concentration fluctuations of about 50–100 ppm can be monitored within measurement times of one second (Frosch et al. 2013a).

Main advantages of enhanced Raman spectroscopic gas sensing include the following:
All gases, except noble gases, can be analysed, including diatomic homonuclear molecules such as oxygenOxygen (O2) (O2), hydrogenHydrogen (H2) (H2), and nitrogen (N2Dinitrogen (N2)).
A whole suite of gases can be identified simultaneously (Fig. 2.16) with no cross sensitivities and the use of only one excitation laser.
A priori unexpected gases can easily be identified in the Raman spectra of complex multigas compositions, in contrast to simple gas sensors that must be designed for all expected gases beforehand.
As direct spectroscopic methodMethod, which is based on the intrinsic molecular vibrations, Raman gas sensing does not need any labels or transducers and does not suffer from saturation, bleeding, poisoning, etc. This optical technique does not need direct physical contact with the analyte gas. Measurements can be performed through an optical window and remote.
The technique is non-consumptive. The gas concentrations are not disturbed due to the measurement process, and small gas exchange processes can be monitored continuously online in closed cycleClose cycle experiments.
The Raman scattering intensity offers perfect linearity with the analyte concentration (Eq. 2.10) and allows for robust instrument calibrationCalibration over a broad concentration range from ppm to pure compounds. Trace gasesTrace gas can be quantified on the background of a higher concentrated gas matrixGas matrix.
The fast Raman spectroscopic measurement enables online monitoring of temporal changes in gas concentrations during process.
Stable gas isotopes can be distinguished (due to changes in the reduced mass and thus spectral position, see Fig. 2.19) and be used as tracers to follow specific pathways.Fig. 2.19

sec.title: Enhanced Raman Spectroscopic Analysis of Greenhouse Gases
sec.p: Research regarding enhanced Raman spectroscopyRaman spectroscopyof biogenic gasesGreenhouse Gases (GHGs) can be divided into three areas: (i) The capability for unambiguous identification and quantification of various gas mixture components to follow the formation, spread, and exchange as well as storageStorage of gases (Frosch et al. 2013a; Jochum et al. 2015a, b; Keiner et al. 2013, 2014, 2015a, b; Sieburg et al. 2017, 2019; Hanf et al. 2015b). One focus is the analysis of the respiratory quotientRespiratory Quotient (RQ) (RQ, CO2Carbon dioxide (CO2) released per O2Oxygen (O2) consumed during respiration) as an indicator of changes in substrate use and metabolism (Jochum et al. 2015a; Keiner et al. 2013; Sieburg et al. 2017; Hanf et al. 2015b); (ii) the monitoring of stable isotopesStable isotope (12/13CO2, 14/15N2, 14/15N2O, and 16/18O2) alongside unlabeled gases as tracers for specific pathways (Knebl et al. 2019; Keiner et al. 2014, 2015a, b); and (iii) the unique ability for direct quantification of nitrogenNitrogen (N) at natural background to study pathways of the nitrogen cycleN cycle (e.g. denitrificationDenitrification, N2Dinitrogen (N2) fixation) (Keiner et al. 2015a; Kumar et al. 2018; Jochum et al. 2017).

The RQRespiratory Quotient (RQ) value was analysed as an indicator of changes in plant metabolism under drought stress (Fig. 2.20) (Hanf et al. 2015b). It was discovered that pine (PinusPinussylvestris) can switch from carbohydrate-dominated respiration to a mixture of substrates during several days of drought stress, but spruce (PiceaPiceaabies) cannot (Hanf et al. 2015b). The onsite analysis of depth profiles of soil gases in the Hainich critical zone exploratory showed that the concentrations of O2Oxygen (O2)and CO2Carbon dioxide (CO2) were largely decoupled, and complex processes in previously uncharacterised environments can be studied (Sieburg et al. 2017). The ability to monitor the inert tracer sulphur hexafluorideSulphur Hexafluoride (SF6), Sulphur hexafluoride (SF6) alongside biogenic gases under consideration allows for thorough online gas leakageLeakage correction to avoid under- or overestimation of biological activity such as respiration or photosynthesis (Fig. 2.21) (Jochum et al. 2015b).Fig. 2.20

The discriminatory power of Raman spectroscopyRaman spectroscopy was used to monitor several stable gas isotopes simultaneously to investigate the labelling of young poplar trees under aphid infestation with 13CO2 to analyse the possible incorporation of 13C13C in defense compounds (Keiner et al. 2014, 2015b). A combination of 13C13C-labelling and RQRespiratory Quotient (RQ) analysis was applied to investigate the microbial degradation of 13C13C-labelled benzene in soil against the background of the heterotrophic soil respirationSoil respiration (Jochum et al. 2015a). Enhanced Raman gas spectroscopySpectroscopy combines the unmatched analytical prowess of Raman spectroscopyRaman spectroscopy with the enhancement of small signals through the sophisticated use of optical cavities (CERSCavity-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (CERS)) and hollow-core optical fibres (FERSFibre-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (FERS)). Enhanced Raman spectroscopyRaman spectroscopy is a powerful technique for simultaneous multigas analysisRaman spectroscopic gas analysis, including N2Dinitrogen (N2), N2ONitrous oxide (N2O), O2Oxygen (O2), H2Hydrogen (H2), CH4Methane (CH4), CO2Carbon dioxide (CO2), and stable isotopesStable isotope (13C13C, 15N15N, and 18O18O). sec.title: GHG Fluxes from Aquatic Systems
sec.p: FollowingAquatictheGreenhouse Gases (GHGs)first set of IPCCIntergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) guidelines being produced (IPCC 1995), further developments were needed to improve national inventory calculations. These included a quantifiable way to determine N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) production after the leachingLeaching and runoff of N from agricultural soils, in order to improve the methodology for calculating annual N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) emissions from agricultural soils at a national level (Mosier et al. 1998). The second phase approach assumes that all N cyclesN cycle within 1 year and makes no allowance for potential sequestration within the soil, which may be subsequently released on longer timescales (Mosier et al. 1998).

Supersaturation of N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) in ground and surface watersWater occurs due to either N2ONitrous oxide (N2O)leachingLeaching from the soil or because microbial processes utilise NLEACHNLEACHto form N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) in the ground and surface watersWater.

The approach taken to determine EF5Emission Factor (EF5) seeks to compare the emission based on the N loading, which is comparable with calculating direct emission factorsEmission Factor (EF) from agricultural soils. For soils, a direct emission factorEmission Factor (EF) is determined by applying a quantity of N to plots and measuring the resulting N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) emissions relative to control plots. A different approach has been taken to determine EF5Emission Factor (EF5). Briefly, the N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) concentration in a waterWater sample is measured, and the degree of N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) saturation is determined. The EF5Emission Factor (EF5) value is then determined based on the ratio of N2O-N: NO3−-N orNitrate (NO3−) on the basis of assumed N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) emissions using the degree of saturation to predict a flux. To use the IPCCIntergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) methodology to determine EF5Emission Factor (EF5) values requires that the concentration of dissolved N2ODissolved N2O is first established so that the flux of N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) can be determined.

Nitrous oxideNitrous oxide (N2O) produced at depth within a soil can be readily dissolved in soil pore water or water draining from the soil in question. A 10 ml volumetric pipette is placed, inverted inside the sample bottle, within the autosampler. The inversion of the pipette allows for simple modifications for length and enables faster filling while simultaneously minimising turbulence during filling (Roper et al. 2013). The inverted pipette means that the waterWater contained in the pipette has a reduced surface area compared to the larger sample bottle. A water sample for dissolved gasDissolved gas determination is taken manually by withdrawing 5 ml of the 9 ml of water from inside each pipette using a syringeSyringe, disposable syringe equipped with a 20-gauge 30.5 cm needle (Popper®, Fisher Scientific) and placing the sample in a 12 ml ExetainerExetainer (Labco International, UK). sec.title: Determining N2O Fluxes from a Water Body
Determining Gas Transfer Velocity (K)
sec.p: The value of k varies due to the turbulent mixingGas transfer velocity of the waterWater body at the waterWater–atmosphere interface. Turbulence within the waterWater body may result from shear stresses on the bed of streamsStreamor riversRiver, or tidal currents and is thus dependent on the depth of the waterWater body and the speed at which it flows. It may also result from the wind. Thus, it can be expected that small, shallow, and sheltered waterWater bodies, such as agricultural drainsAgricultural drains, will have values of k more strongly influenced by waterWater depth and/or speed (current), while deeper large open expanses of waterWater such as estuaries, large riversRiver, lakes, and oceans will be more strongly influenced by wind, although tidal currents in estuaries and winds that oppose the direction of the waterWater body current can all influence turbulence.

MethodsMethod to derive values for k include (i) measuring the N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) flux using floating chambers (or fixed chamber) and back calculating k, (ii) using published relationships between k and wind speed to derive the value of k, (iii) tracer gas methodsMethod, and (iv) modelling of waterWater body and micrometeorological parameters, or a combination of these approaches.

Measuring the N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) flux with chambers that float on the waterWater body surface is commonly performed. Besides the requirements of chamber design that optimise sensitivity of the measurement, discussed elsewhere for land-based gas measurement (see Sect. 2.2), the chamber must obviously float, but with minimal intrusion into the water body when floating, have a vent to allow equilibrationEquilibration, Equilibrium of the headspace pressure during the placement of the chamber on the water surface, be insulated to prevent temperatureTemperature regulation, temperature changes inside the chamber, and have a low profile to reduce the influence of wind moving the chamber across the water surface at directions opposed to the current. Such an effect creates additional turbulence and can lead to an overestimation of N2O fluxes (Clough et al. 2007b). Similarly, tethering the chamber so that it cannot drift in the current can also increase turbulence inside the chamber and lead to erroneous fluxes being derived (Hartman and Hammond 1984). If the waterWater body is large, the chamber can be tethered to a boat, with a slackline, while both drift in the current (Beaulieu et al. 2012). Procedures for gas sampling, analysis, and calculation of fluxes are consistent with those for land-based chambers (Sect. 2.2): best practice involves taking several chamber headspace samples over time to enable the fitting of modelsModel to determine if the change in headspace N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) concentration fits a linear or non-linear trend, with fluxes calculated accordingly (Beaulieu et al. 2012; Hutchinson and Mosier 1981) (Plate 2.19).Plate 2.19
Floating chambers being used to determine the N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) flux from the LII riverRiver in Canterbury, New Zealand. Note the high number of replicates. Floating chambers are drifting freely in the current, but loosely tethered to a person walking alongside on the river bank who can retrieve the chambers for sampling (a), and fixed chamber being used to determine the GHGsGreenhouse Gases (GHGs) flux from the riverRiver in China that can be raised or lowered with the fluctuation of waterWater level (b)

For large waterWater bodies, the value of k can be estimated using its relationship to wind speed (de Wilde and de Bie 2000; Barnes and Owens 1998) using equations that derive k from wind speed (Liss and Merlivat 1986; Wanninkhof 1992; Clark et al. 1994; Wanninkhof 2014). This methodology is best suited to deeper large open expanses of water, such as estuaries, lakes, and oceans. However, caution is required, as waterWater currents can still affect turbulence in large open waterWater bodies as demonstrated by Beaulieu et al. (2012): the value of k in the Ohio RiverRiver was attributed to not just wind but both current and wind speeds, with 46% of k at low wind speeds (0.5 m s−1) resulting from waterWater currents which were reduced to 11% at higher wind speed (>2.0 m s−1).

The principle of the tracer gas methodTracer gas method is to release a soluble gas at a given point in the waterWater body under study and to follow the dissipation of the injected gas over distance and time. Trace gasTrace gas studies have been performed in lakes (Cole and Caraco 1998), oceans (Wanninkhof 1992), estuaries (Clark et al. 1994), and streamsStream and drainage ditches (Harrison and Matson 2003; Premaratne et al. 2017). Trace gasesTrace gas should be absent from the study environment, and sulphur hexafluorideSulphur Hexafluoride (SF6), Sulphur hexafluoride (SF6), methyl chlorideMethyl Chloride (CH3Cl) (CH3Cl), propanePropane (C3H8) (C3H8), kryptonKrypton (Kr) (Kr), and Freon-12 have been used. Studies by Jin et al. (2012) and Premaratne et al. (2017) provide examples of the technique using CH3H8, which is briefly described below. The tracer gas is first bubbled through a large container of waterWater to saturate the waterWater body with C3H8Propane (C3H8). Typically, this is a large carboy with the exact volume-dependent on the size of the water body under study and the ensuing release rate of the gas saturated water into the water body, assumed here to be a streamStream. Also dissolved in the water is an inert chemical tracer that can be used to estimate streamStream flow rate and dilutionDilution of the added water. For example, this inert tracer might be bromideBromide (Br−) or a chloride salt (Cl−). If the background conductivity of the water body is high, then a dye such as the rhodamine dye may be used. The water is injected at a known constant rate into the streamStream, using a peristaltic pump. Combining gas and chemical tracers in the one vessel prevents uneven mixing of the tracers in the streamStreamfollowing injectionInjection, sample injection, which might occur if they are added from separate containers. However, for larger water bodies, this will be impractical, and the gas tracer will be delivered by gently releasing gas directly into the water body. For example, in the Iroquois RiverRiver, Laursen and Seitzinger (2004) introduced tracer gas by staking a perforated garden hose to the streamStream bed perpendicular to the channel flow direction. Sampling stations are set up at intervals downstreamStream of the tracer injectionInjection, sample injection site, dependent on-streamStream speed and flow, with the first site several metres downstream to ensure adequate mixing of the injected water and to allow for any ebullition of tracer gas bubbles to be completed. Again, with larger riversRiver, these sampling stations will be at greater distances (e.g. kilometres) from the tracer injectionInjection, sample injection site. At the sampling stations, waterWater samples are taken to determine trace gasTrace gas concentrations using the equilibrationEquilibration, Equilibrium technique, and floating chambers may also be deployed to measure trace gasTrace gas fluxes. In addition, waterWater chemistry, micrometeorological parameters (e.g. wind speed, air temperatureTemperature regulation, temperature, and solar irradiance) and hydrological parameters are measured: depth, h (m); width, w (m); and velocity, U (m s−1) enable the volumetric flow (Q, m3 s−1) to be calculated.

sec.title: Models for Determining N2O Fluxes from Water Bodies
Other Factors to Consider
sec.p: Besides measurements of dissolved gasesDissolved gas in the waterWater body, consideration should also be given to reporting other parameters or features at the site that will enable interpretation of the results, extrapolation of the results, modelling, and comparison with other studies. WaterWater bodies such as drainsDrain and streamsStream are unlikely to have constant chemistry throughout the day, and diel variation is commonly observed in temperatureTemperature regulation, temperature, dissolved oxygenOxygen (O2) (DO), and pHPH, soil pH (Harrison et al. 2005; Clough et al. 2007b). Similarly, seasonal changes also occur. Such changes have implications for N cycling, and thus the amount of N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) dissolved in the waterWater. A key driver of DO, besides respiration, is the rate of photosynthesis. This is affected by how clear the waterWater is; so measurements of turbidity and sunshine hours should also be reported. Similarly, wind speed and direction are other critical parameters to gather. Dissolved organic CCarbon (C) and inorganic-N species, both known to affect N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) production or consumption transformationsN transformation, should also be reported.

sec.title: Determining EF5
sec.p: Once the N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) flux has been established, the EF5Emission Factor (EF5) value can be established. First, the N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) flux is converted to an N2O-N flux. This will have units of mass of N per unit area per unit time. To establish the EF5Emission Factor (EF5) value, the amount of Nitrate (NO3−)NO3− moving through a given area per unit time is then calculated, which then enables the EF5Emission Factor (EF5) ratio to be determined. For example, if a 1-m-wide streamStream is 1 m deep and has a speed of 1 m s−1, then the streamStream flows through one square metre every second. If the Nitrate (NO3−)NO3−-N concentration in the waterWater is 0.2 mg l−1, then 0.2 g of NO3−-N flows through underneath the 1 m2 surface every second. If an N2O-N flux is 0.5 µg m−2 s−1, then the ratio is 0.5 × 10−6: 0.2, or 2.5 × 10−6. The EF5Emission Factor (EF5) value is then determined based on the ratio of N2O-N: NO3−-N or on the basis of assumed N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) emissions using the degree of saturation to predict a flux.

Units of N2O-N flux and Nitrate (NO3−)NO3-N can be adjusted for the time period concerned. Obviously, streamStreamchemistry and N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) fluxes are dynamic, and so it is expected that EF5Emission Factor (EF5) could also vary. Thus, modelling of these parameters at varying scales is useful for predicting EF5Emission Factor (EF5) over different periods. For example, Reay et al. (2003) successfully modelled the N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) flux along a drainDrainwith N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) emissions calculated on a “per metre of streamStream” basis, with predicted N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) losses from the preceding 1 m stretch being subtracted from the dissolved N2ODissolved N2O concentration for each 1 m section of the drainDrain.

sec.title: Indirect GHG Emissions–Ammonia Emissions
sec.p: Ammonia (NH3Ammonia (NH3)) itself has noGreenhouse Gases (GHGs) direct greenhouse effectAmmonia (NH3). It is a gas with relatively low residence time in the atmosphere (2–10 days) compared to some GHGGreenhouse Gases (GHGs), such as CO2Carbon dioxide (CO2) (3–4 years), CH4Methane (CH4) (9 years), and N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) (150 years) (Hobbs 2000). However, after NH3 enters the atmosphere and reacts with acids forming salts, it returns to the earth’s surface and causes N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) emissions similar to a fertiliser-N application. When the soil is subjected to conditions near to optimal for urease activity (e.g. pHPH, soil pH close to neutrality, soil moisture near the field capacity, temperatureTemperature regulation, temperature > 30 °C), the N losses through NH3 volatilisationAmmonia volatilization from ureaUrea-based fertilisers applied on soil surface can be as high as 50% (Rochette et al. 2013; Martins et al. 2017). Therefore, the measurement of NH3 emission is important to estimate indirect N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) emissions derived from soil amendmentsSoil amendment, such as ureaUrea-based fertilisers, green manures, animal excreta, or ammoniumAmmonium (NH4+)-based fertilisers in different soils. A default emission factorEmission Factor (EF)defined by IPCCIntergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), known as EF4, can be applied for the estimation of indirect N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) emissions derived from volatilisation of NH3 and other nitrogen oxides (NOx) (de Klein et al. 2007). The mean value of EF4, considering the N volatilisationVolatilization and consequent re-deposition, is 0.01 kg N2O-N per kg N volatilised as NH3 + NOx with an uncertainty ranging from 0.002 to 0.05 (de Klein et al. 2007). Management options that reduce NH3Ammonia (NH3)volatilisationAmmonia volatilization from soils are considered mitigating practices because they reduce indirect N2ONitrous oxide (N2O)emissionsIntergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) (IPCC 2014; Lam et al. 2017).

There is a considerable range of non-isotopic methodsMethod that can be used to quantify the NH3Ammonia (NH3)volatilisationAmmonia volatilization from soils. Chamber-based methods are the most common. They are generally inexpensive compared to other more sophisticated methodsMethod, such as micrometeorological, and are easier to install and handle. On the other hand, the micrometeorological methodMethod has the advantage of being more representative for larger areas and therefore are more representative of the field scale. The classical micrometeorological methodMethod to measure NH3-N emissions is the mass balance integrated horizontal fluxIntegrated Horizontal Flux (IHF) (IHF) methodMethod (Leuning et al. 1985). This methodMethod is based on the assumption that “vertical NH3-N flux from a fertilised area of limited upwindUpwind extent” is equal to “the integrated horizontal NH3-N flux at known downwind distance” (Wilson et al. 1983). Chamber-based methodsMethod have been used since the mid-twentieth century to test the effectiveness of N management practices aiming at a reduction of NH3Ammonia (NH3)-N losses (Volk 1959). An example of a chamber design used to collect volatilised NH3Ammonia (NH3) is the semi-open collector described by Nômmik (1973). Another common type of chamber is based on the use of a low vacuum system to collect NH3Ammonia (NH3), which consists of tubes connecting the chamber to a vacuum pumpVacuum pump and a small flask containing an acid solution used as NH3Ammonia (NH3) trap (Kissel et al. 1977).

To warrant the precisionPrecision and accuracyAccuracy of measurements, i.e. reducing the uncertainty for extrapolation of NH3Ammonia (NH3)-N losses to larger areas, some procedures of installation and handling the chambers under field conditions should be warranted. For instance, the installation and replacement of the acid traps should be performed in a short period to avoid a time-dependent bias. MethodsMethod employing soil collars should be preinstalled at least 24 h before the beginning of measurements to avoid undesirable effects of soil physical disturbanceDisturbance on the NH3Ammonia (NH3)volatilisationAmmonia volatilization process. Moreover, the efficiency of NH3Ammonia (NH3) captured by some type of chambers is usually not 100%, demanding the use of correction factorsCorrection factor for the final calculation of NH3Ammonia (NH3)-N losses. These correction factorsCorrection factor are usually predefined in previous studies in which calibrationCalibration is performed using reference methodsMethod, such as the 15N15N-balance methodMethod (Araujo et al. 2009; Jantalia et al. 2012; Martins et al. 2021b).

sec.title: A Simple Low-Cost Chamber to Quantify NH3 Volatilisation
sec.p:
Among all methodsMethodfor NH3Ammonia (NH3)volatilisationAmmonia volatilization measurements, a low-cost chamberLow-cost chamber has been used successfully under field conditions (Araújo et al. 2009; Nichols et al. 2018). This chamber costs less than one US dollar and can be manufactured in any region of the world, including those regions with limited financial resources for scientific research. Studies conducted under field conditions have been showing that this chamber can be used with sufficient accuracyAccuracy and precisionPrecision in experiments aiming at testing management practices for NH3-N loss abatement. Details of the design of this chamber were presented by Araújo et al. (2009), Jantalia et al. (2012), Nichols et al. (2018), and Martins et al. (2021a,b). Briefly, this chamber is made by cutting the bottom of a plastic soda bottle. After cutting, the bottom is attached to the top of the bottle finish, serving as protection against rainwaterWater. A vertically hung foam strip (250 mm long, 25 mm wide, and 3 mm thick) pre-soaked in a 10 ml solution of sulphuric acid (1 mol/L) plus glycerol (2%, v/v) is placed inside the chamber to capture NH3Ammonia (NH3). A small plastic pot is used inside the chamber to retain the remaining acid solution not absorbed by the foam. A basket made of wire and hung from the bottle finish is used as a support for the plastic pot and the foam inside the chamber. The steps to manufacture and anchor the chamber in the soil are shown in Plates 2.23 and 2.24.Plate 2.23
Steps to manufacture a low-cost chamberLow-cost chamber to measure ammoniaAmmonia (NH3) volatilisationAmmonia volatilization under field conditions (Araujo et al. 2009; Martins et al. 2021b)Plate 2.24
A simple design of an open chamberOpen chamber after the assemblage of the parts. A correction factorCorrection factor of 1.7 is used to convert the amount of NH3Ammonia (NH3) trapped in the total volatilised NH3 (Araujo et al. 2009; Martins et al. 2021b)

Metallic supports can be used to anchor the chamber (Plate 2.24). The amounts of “outside NH3”, i.e. NH3Ammonia (NH3) not directly derived from soil, are usually not significant in this type of chamber, even though the non-significance of the amount of “outside NH3” can be checked by installing some blank chambers in the area of NH3 measurements (e.g. one “blank” chamber per experimental block). Some eventual NH3 detected in these “blank” chambers can be subtracted from the total NH3Ammonia (NH3) trapped in the chambers installed in treated and control plots. This “blank” chamber is the same described above, but the soil surface is covered using an impermeable barrier (e.g. an inert and impermeable plastic sheet).

Considering that the area circumscribed by chambers (<0.1 m2) is usually much smaller than the final area used for extrapolation of theAmmonia (NH3) NH3-N losses (e.g. hectare), the minimisation of the inherent uncertainty depends on the use of some strategies. For instance, one way of reducing uncertainty is the employment of multiple chambers per field plot. This strategy can increase the capacity of the detection of significant NH3-N loss abatement by adequate N management practices. In a field plot experiment, Martins et al. (2021a) estimated that, by using five chambers per plot (31 m2), the margin of error was less than 15% of the real NH3-N loss. To optimise the fieldwork and the laboratory analyses, the use of multiple chambers per plot can be employed only in the critical periods of emissions, i.e. focusing sampling in the period of a high probability of occurrence of significant NH3 fluxes and associated errors. For example, after easy hydrolysable N sources are deposited on the soil surface (e.g. fertilisers, excreta), the bulk of NH3-N losses usually occurs in the first 2 weeks after N depositionN deposition. Therefore, using multiple chambers in this period has a high probability of significantly reducing errors associated with the use of chambers. It is worth noting that the conventional use of multiple plots per treatment (replicates) in field experiments intrinsically improves the precisionPrecision of NH3-N loss estimates, even when using a single chamber per plot.

In addition, a significant part of the errors in measurements of Ammonia (NH3)NH3 volatilisationAmmonia volatilization can be reduced if it is ensured that the amounts of fertiliser applied in the relatively small area circumscribed by the chamber are equivalent to the N rate tested in the area of the plot, in kg ha-1. The use of microplots inside the main field plots reduces this kind of uncertainty. The foams capturing NH3Ammonia (NH3) in the “plastic bottle” chamber should be periodically replaced in the course of the measurement period. The frequency of replacement depends on the purpose of the NH3-N loss quantification. When the measurements are performed to understand the temporal dynamics of NH3-N losses, more frequent replacements of the foams should be adopted (e.g. every 2 days or on a daily basis). By contrast, when the purpose is to assess only the total amount of NH3-N loss, the intervals of replacements of the foams can be increased, but not exceeding 5 days (Araújo et al. 2009). Considering the amount of sulphuric acid in the solution, each foam has the NH3Ammonia (NH3) trapping capacity equivalent of more than 300 kg N ha-1. Considering also that the foams are replaced several times in the course of the measurement period, the saturation or reduction of trapping efficiency is very unlikely for the usual NH3Ammonia (NH3) fluxes measured in soils.

When an easily hydrolysable N source is applied, such as ureaUrea-based fertilisers in agricultural soils or urine in pastureGrassland, pasture areas, the significant fluxes of NH3Ammonia (NH3) are usually very intense in the first days and usually return to the background NH3Ammonia (NH3) emissions in the first two weeks (Martins et al. 2021a). On the other hand, the application of more recalcitrant NRecalcitrant N sources causes prolonged NH3Ammonia (NH3) fluxes above the background emissionsBackground, background emission, demanding measurements for longer periods. For instance, the measurements of NH3Ammonia (NH3)-N losses derived from plant residuesPlant residue with high CCarbon (C)/N ratio usually should be performed for several weeks or months after the amendment. If promptly performed after collection in the field, the analysis of N in the foams can indicate the need for further NH3Ammonia (NH3)-N measurements.

The plastic pots with the collected foam strips should be transported to the laboratory for the extraction of N trapped in the foams (NH4+formAmmonium (NH4+)). To extract theAmmonium (NH4+) NH4+ from the foams, the content of the plastic pots (foam + solution) is transferred to an Erlenmeyer flask, and then deionised waterWater (40 ml) is added for the extraction of theAmmonium (NH4+) NH4+. Alternatively, KCl solutions can also be used (Jantalia et al. 2012), but some tests indicate that pure distilled waterWater is able to extract the total quantity of N trapped in the foams. After that, the Erlenmeyer flasks are shaken on an orbital shaker, usually for less than 30 min (Plate 2.25).Plate 2.25
Orbital shaker with the Erlenmeyer flasks used for the extraction ofAmmonium (NH4+) NH4+ from the foams coming from the chambers

After theAmmonium (NH4+) NH4+ is extracted from the foams, the N concentration of the extraction solution can be analysed using one of the many methodsMethod available (Bremner 1965; Keeney and Nelson 1982). Some examples of usual methodsMethod for the determination of NH4+-N inAmmonium (NH4+) solution are continuous flow analysis, steam distillation, and colorimetric techniques. Continuous flow system, such as flow injection analysisFlow Injection Analysis (FIA) (FIA), is quite adequate because they are usually rapid and very sensitive, which are significant advantages when working with a high number of chambers and with many replacements of foams during the period of measurement of NH3Ammonia (NH3)volatilisationAmmonia volatilization. StandardStandard solutions of ammoniumAmmonium (NH4+) salt (e.g. sulphate) should be analysed along with the extraction solutions. An example spreadsheet for illustrating the calculation for the conversion of the N concentration in the extraction solutions to the total NH3Ammonia (NH3)-N loss per hectare is detailed in Table 2.7. In the example shown below, considering a total NH3-N loss of 54.90 kg N ha−1 in the N-fertilised treatment and subtracting 0.79 kg N ha−1 (Zero N treatment, i.e. “backgroundBackground, background emission” emission), we estimated that 36% of the applied N was lost as volatilised NH3Ammonia (NH3).

sec.title: Gas Production Processes in Terrestrial Ecosystems
sec.p: The totalTerrestrial ecosystem production of a certain gas from the soil is often the sum of several soil fluxes that can occur in diverse micrositesMicrosite of the soil (e.g. aerobicAerobic and anaerobicAnaerobicmicrositesMicrosite), for instance, soil microbial processes for N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) production, including nitrificationNitrification, denitrificationDenitrification, co-denitrificationCo-denitrification, and organic NOrganic N (Norg) oxidation to mineral N (Zaman et al. 2012; Butterbach-Bahl et al. 2013; Müller et al. 2014; Smith 2017). The microbial processes of N2ONitrous oxide (N2O) and non-greenhouse gasGreenhouse Gases (GHGs)N2Dinitrogen (N2) production in soils, sediments, and groundwaterGroundwater across the landscape may occur simultaneously and depend on the physical (moisture contents or O2Oxygen (O2) level and permeability) and chemical conditions [N form (i.e. organic NOrganic N (Norg), NH4+-NAmmonium (NH4+), NO2−-N, and NO3−-N), pHPH, soil pHand organic COrganic C (Corg) contents] (Zaman et al. 2012). Such complexity of gas production processes in soil makes the precise measurements of GHGGreenhouse Gases (GHGs) flux, especially across different agroecosystemsAgroecosystem, very difficult and challenging. The identification of process and pathway-specific GHGGreenhouse Gases (GHGs) fluxes can be tackled by suitable stable isotopeStable isotope-tracing techniques which are described in detail in Chap. 7.
